Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Colleen Delaney is "Quantum combinatorics, categorification, and information." The host institution for the fellowship Indiana University the sponsoring scientist is Noah Snyder.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research at the interface of algebra, topology, and physics that contributes to the mathematical classification of certain 2-dimensional quantum systems that exhibit a phenomenon known as "topological order". In such systems, quasiparticle excitations called anyons exhibit behavior that generalizes that of ordinary 3-dimensional bosons and fermions in a manner that can be exploited for fault-tolerant encoding and processing of quantum information.

The quantum field theory that dictates the physics of these anyons endows them with a mathematical model by way of algebraic objects known as modular fusion categories, which in turn encode topological invariants of low-dimensional shapes like knots, surfaces, and 3-manifolds. This mathematical framework can then be used to classify and characterize topological order, a scientific program that can be thought of as analogous to building the periodic table for ordinary matter comprised of protons, neutrons, and electrons.

The work carried out under this award was specifically interested in a novel mathematical construction for producing new theories from existing ones by a combinatorial procedure called "zesting". Both the development of this construction and its application were focuses of the PIs research program during the award period. The construction was developed with collaborators Galindo, Rowell, Plavnik, and Zhang and also facilitated by the American Institute of Mathematics SQuaRE program.

One subsequent application of the construction was discovered by the PI in collaboration with Plavnik and an undergraduate student researcher, who was mentored by the PI and Plavnik through Indiana University’s NSF-sponsored REU program. The team showed that certain subtle examples of topological order which fail to be classified by the standard pair of invariants that encodes the mutual and self-statistics of anyons can be realized by the new zesting construction.

Additional mentoring activities undertaken by the PI under this award included working with Indiana University's Emerging Scholars Program to provide research experiences for undergraduate women majoring in STEM fields.
